subject: Re: On the Unicode proposal
msgSnippet: Firstly, let me say that I am sorry not to have been active recently: was on holiday.  I am very happy that people are interested in getting QS into Unicode,
messageBody:
Firstly, let me say that I am sorry not to have been active recently:
was on holiday. I am very happy that people are interested in getting
QS into Unicode, despite Mr. Everson's lack of enthusiasm for the
endeavor.

I think you are right on the mark when you say the font layer should
handle the differences between junior and senior QS. The encoding
would be identical for both, but the display would be different.

Another mistake in the shavian unicode mapping that I would prefer to
not see repeated would be the inclusion of common ligatures. Again,
these are better handled by the font layer and their use in the
encoding causes all sorts of problems for sorting.

As for the ordering, I agree that it should mostly follow the original
QS manual, except that the extended letters "Loch" and "llan" and the
alternate letters "excite" and "examine" were not on the original
chart. (For the latter two, I personally prefer NOT to use them; but
I feel they should be included for completeness.) On my encoding
proposal (the message 375 that Tim refers to), I included them after
the other consonants and before the vowels.

One thing that I think will really help with the unicode proposal is
actually having a body of work in Quickscript. I do not know offhand
if there is already an electronic version on Androcles and the Lion in
Shavian, but that would seem to be a simple conversion if so. Beyond
that, it would be great if we could get other examples of works
produced (entirely or in part) in Quickscript. Even if these are
produced using the current 'overloaded roman' encoding, translating
them after the fact to a unicode encoding would be trivial (I know
that AMD64 [if that _is_ your real name ;)] is a perl hacker, as am I).

oliver
